body: The error message says the `init` module does not have `Constant`. Maybe you happen to be using a very old version of MXNet?

Is this your first installation or you cloned properly with --recursive? If it is not, it could be the problem of the outdated or insufficient dependencies for mshadow.
1. Delete the whole mxnet and reinstall all with git clone https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet --recursive
2. or move to the mxnet/mshadow then git pull origin master to get update the dependency.

I'm using what comes as the default in the DeepLearning AMI. Is there a way
I can upgrade that?

This issuse could be closed.

@piiswrong disagree with you. We need to have solid high-level introduction to what MXNet is and what purpose it serves. Right now MXNet assumes the readers already knows what a deep learning acceleration library is, which is unacceptable. I agree that Installation needs to be as easy to reach as possible. One solution for is we can flip the order of the documents.

@piiswrong We will have a new home page that will point to each document, however they both need to live within the Getting Started section. Let's change the order and approve this quickly so we can get to work on the improved home page.
@kevinthesun Could you resize the images so that they are appropriate for the document?
In general yes. But this particular section is more like "why deep learning" than "why mxnet". It's probably better to call it "What's MXNet"
@piiswrong No it's not. I imagine you're mistaken because you're only reading the first paragraph (perhaps because the picture is too big). It's a full-page document.
Also this image is too long. A thinner banner like image would be better as it won't hide the content below.

does installation have to be in the same page as intro? How about two buttons on the front page? Its fairly common

BTW we don't put images in main repo. They should go in web-data.

@xinq2016, @piiswrong: I can finally reproduce this problem. I have confirmed that this example works when you delete all the new ctc_loss files (the folder `ctc_include`, `ctc_loss.cc`, `ctc_loss.cu` and `ctc_loss-inl.h`), but breaks when you include them.

@sbodenstein 
OK, thanks a lot. 
It works now.

Many thanks
Putting binaries in code repo will lead to extremely large repo size and clone can take a very long time. Code repo should only contain txt.
@jay960702 try to do `sudo apt-get install libtiff4-dev`
@piiswrong still that doesn't mean we need to dump all the static files in another repo does it? what are the alternatives? S3?

Hosting it on another server is more or less the same thing. Doing it ourselves means we need to handle DNS/CDN  and all that madness.

An alternative would be to put the docs folder itself in another repo.

@piiswrong let's work out the long-term solution offline. In the short run - @kevinthesun can you please:
* resize the images
* commit them to the crazy image repo 
* flip the order of the documents so the Installation page appears first

Thanks!
@IvyGongoogle Thank you very much

```

  7 num_embed = 300

 19 m.cnn_exec.forward(is_train=False)
 20 print m.cnn_exec.outputs[0].asnumpy()
 21 print y[:50]
```

@matteo: we could do the following: if epsilon is smaller than or equal to `10^-5`, then set eps to `10^-4` and subtract the difference from the moving variance. This will guarantee that the predictions are the same as caffe, and that it can run on cuDNN.
This issue is related to #6177 where I located the issue.

Isn't this the latest release? Would you still suggest I update?

I am sorry that I don't have a Windows machine with GPU.

A two-round installation is required for R installation. We need to generate NAMESPACE in the first round.

Please see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L324-L331

I am sorry that I have no idea why your R hanged.

My suggestion is (1) removing the usage of NNPACK and MKL and (2) reinstalling.
@sbodenstein: good suggestion, I added that. Numerical predictions are now fully restored (up to a usual ~10^-6 relative difference), altough the way I implemented it is a bit ugly.

Yes, it seem to be the latest stable release. However, `mx.init.Constant` was added after that. You can try to upgrade to the pre-release v0.9.5 or if the only thing you need is `mx.init.Constant`, you could probably just copy that piece of code from the latest github code. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/initializer.py#L346

@piiswrong dll dep is merged

see http://pytorch.org/docs/nn.html#convtranspose2d and https://keras.io/layers/convolutional/#conv2dtranspose and the corresponding tensorflow doc for how these ops should be documented. Note that our implementation is slightly different here and there. So you cannot simple copy their doc.

In general we are trying to improve the doc to provide more information, instead of just normalizing punctuation.

Please read the doc (and code if necessary) to understand what each operator is doing.

Could you resolve the conflicts?

mxnet engine is already async, so there is no need of multiprocess training.
you can collect input from multiple child processes and train in the main process

My issue was resolved by tweaking the _update_params(..) function in [model.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py) with the function below. 

NOTE: this does not support multiple devices, the way the original MxNet code does. It rather changes the dictionary keys (index passed to updater) to the parameter names, so that if the graph is dynamic, the newly created states in updater are attached to the right names. This is essential since for a dynamic graph list indexing is not preserved from one graph to the next. Therefore, the initial implementation does not support it. However, as noted this is just a temporary hack.

After changing the function, the arg_names and param_names should be passed to _update_params() in function update() in file [module.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/module.py).
i.e.: 
```
_update_params(self._exec_group.param_arrays,
                           self._exec_group.grad_arrays,
                           updater=self._updater,
                           num_device=len(self._context),
                           kvstore=self._kvstore,
                           param_names=self._exec_group.param_names,
                           arg_names=self._exec_group.arg_names)
```

This is the tweaked version of _update_params(..) in file  [model.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py)

```
def _update_params(param_arrays, grad_arrays, updater, num_device,
                   kvstore=None, param_names=None, arg_names=None):
    """ Perform update of param_arrays from grad_arrays not on kvstore."""
    if param_names==None and arg_names==None:
        for index, pair in enumerate(zip(param_arrays, grad_arrays)):
            arg_list, grad_list = pair
            if grad_list[0] is None:
                continue
            if kvstore:
                # push gradient, priority is negative index
                kvstore.push(index, grad_list, priority=-index)
                # pull back the sum gradients, to the same locations.
                kvstore.pull(index, grad_list, priority=-index)
            for k, p in enumerate(zip(arg_list, grad_list)):
                # faked an index here, to make optimizer create diff
                # state for the same index but on diff devs, TODO(mli)
                # use a better solution latter
                w, g = p
                updater(index*num_device+k, g, w)
    elif param_names!=None and arg_names!=None:
        ctr = -1
        for i, index in enumerate(arg_names):
            if index in param_names:
                ctr += 1
                arg_list  = param_arrays[ctr]
                grad_list = grad_arrays[ctr]

                if grad_list[0] is None:
                    continue
                if kvstore:
                    # push gradient, priority is negative index
                    kvstore.push(ctr, grad_list, priority=-ctr)
                    # pull back the sum gradients, to the same locations.
                    kvstore.pull(ctr, grad_list, priority=-ctr)

                for k, p in enumerate(zip(arg_list, grad_list)):
                    w, g = p
                    # This deos not support the diff device implemented in the 
                    # if statement above. This is a hack for TreeLSTM application
                    # with different structures per sample
                    updater(index, g, w)
    else:
        raise AssertionError("Both arg_names (%s) and param_names (%s) should be fed."
                             %(str(arg_names), str(param_names)))
```

scratch

```
>>> A.size

>>> A.shape

```

1410065408

@zackchase @piiswrong @szha

Also this:

```
>>> import mxnet as mx
>>> A = mx.nd.empty((2**32, 1))
>>> A.asnumpy()
array([], shape=(0, 1), dtype=float32)
```

It was pointed out that ```index_t``` on [this line](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/include/nnvm/tuple.h#L391) could be the problem since this is just an alias for ```uint32_t``` (see [here](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/include/nnvm/tuple.h#L19))
@dleen Thanks for this reason, is there any solution for this?
I am going to see if changing the local variables of the [Size](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/include/nnvm/tuple.h#L389) method to all be ```size_t``` helps.

@piiswrong , @precedenceguo 

Now, I finished test.

1. I tested in voc07
with fix_gamma=True at 'bn_data',

|    | startswith or in | fixed_params | mAP |  |
| - | --------------  | ------------- | --- | -- |
| 1-1 | startswith          | gamma, beta  | 74.33%| current setting |
| 1-2 | startswith        | bn0, bn_data | 74.85%|
| 1-3 | in                      | gamma, beta | 75.01% |

with fix_gamma=False at 'bn_data',

| | startswith or in | fixed_params | mAP |  |
| - | --------------  | ------------- | --- | -- |
| 1-4 | startswith        | bn0, bn_data | 75.26%|
| 1-5 | in                      | gamma, beta | 75.03% |

in voc07, 1-4 and 1-5 shows best performance.

2. For more test, I used voc07+12.

| | startswith or in | fixed_params | fixed_gamma=True or False | mAP |
| - | --------------- | ------------- | ---------------------------- | ---- |
| 2-1 | startswith | bn0, bn_data | True | 79.48% |
| 2-2 | startswith | bn0, bn_data | False | 80.12% |
| 2-3 | in | gamma, beta | True | 80.14% |
| 2-4 | in | gamma, beta | False | 79.88% |

in voc07+12, 2-3 and 2-4 shows best performance.

As @precedenceguo recommends, changing from 'startswith' to 'in' is a good choice simply and get good results as 75.01% in voc07, 80.14% in voc07+12.

But what I concern is that 1) changing from 'startswith' to 'in' with 'gamma, beta' means all parameters of batch normalization are fixed as pretrained values and are not trained anymore even though it was pretrained using imagenet.

Anyway, I think @precedenceguo's recommendation is good option.
If both of you are agree, I'll make update.
